courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Comparative-Historical Method in Educational Research
courses.description: This module is designed to provide a systematic explication to the theoretical perspectives and research methods of comparative and historical study in the social sciences and education. It aims to familiarize students with the methodology of comparative and historical studies on societal and/ or institutional level. The modules will cover topics such as: conception of Verstehen and the theoretical foundation of interpretative research, the logic and assumptions of comparative and historical research, methods and procedures in comparative and historical research, and review of local and foreign examples of comparative and historical studies in education and the social sciences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, MA Early Child Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Eng Lang Teach, MSc Math Edu, MA Sch Guid & Counsel, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, Doctor of Edu & PhD Edu.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to the course: Historical method in education research; the relationship between History and Sociology; Historical consciousness-conceptualizing or theorising time, structure and agency
2. Constructionist perspective on historical method: archives, oral history, historical records and selection bias
3. Comparative analysis of marco-social phenomena: Why C-H analysis? case studies, logic of comparison: variation across space and time, non-experimental research design, units of analysis, conceptual equivalence, comparable measures, Galton’s problem
4. Comparative-historical methodology: historical sociology and comparative methods; the way of huge comparisons of big structures and large processes; dialogue of ideas and evidence, (Ideal type, necessary and sufficient causes, multiple conjunctural causation, and counterfactual reasoning, path dependence, contingency, temporality, events; causal explanation/ interpretation; deterministic vs probalistic causation, inference/ reasoning based on a small number of cases; trajectory; typology)
5. Comparative-historical methodology: Cont’d
6. Back to philosophy of history again: The nature and status of historical knowledge: fact/ truth, time; Post-modern Historiography; Deconstructionist perspective on historical method: hermeneutics, narrative, discourse, metahistory and theory
7. Conclusion

courses.title: Administrative and Organizational Theory
courses.description: Successful leaders, managers, and administrators underpin their behaviours and practices with a strong foundation of theoretical knowledge and conceptual ability. Accordingly, this course aims at developing students’ theoretical and conceptual abilities. It introduces students to a range of important administrative and organizational theories and perspectives which have influenced management practice at all levels, from system to school, over the past century. These theories and perspectives adopt a wide purview, including structural, human resource, political, symbolic and cultural dimensions. Opportunities will be provided for students to apply the theories and perspectives to current education policy and school management issues in Hong Kong.

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Psychological Development of Teachers
courses.description: Taking the perspective of developmental psychology, this course aims at illuminating teachers on the features and relatedness of the following three processes: "know yourself", "develop yourself", and "develop your student". The curriculum draws substantially on the contemporary theories and research of adult development. Its focus lies in discussing the possibilities and dynamics of teacher development in different realms including cognitive and intellectual, moral and aesthetic, social and affective. The domains of self-development and spiritual development will also be explored. The idea of teacher development as an essential resource for student development serves as a main thread throughout the discussion. Special attention will be given to problems and issues that arise in teachers' work environment including the development of teaching and learning styles, conflict resolution, coping with stress and burnout, expertise development, and reflective practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, MA Early Child Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, Doctor of Edu & PhD Edu.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students are expected to:
(a) understand the context and the dynamic of adult development in general and teacher development in particular
(b) understand the different theoretical perspectives in explaining cognitive, moral, aesthetic, affective, social, self, and spiritual development in adulthood
(c) understand the key issues concerning teacher development (e.g., learning and teaching styles, conflict resolution, coping with stress and burnout, pedagogical expertise, and reflective practice) from both the theoretical and practical levels
(d) understand the dialectic between theory and practice
(e) cultivate their reflectivity by involving themselves in an innovative self-experiment
(f) cultivate their abilities in the application, analysis, synthesis and evaluation of related knowledge by accomplishing a mini-project
(g) enhance their sensitivity to ongoing issues of teacher development
(h) reflect upon the relation between teacher development and student development

courses.description: This course focuses on the inquiry of: 1) different perspectives on curriculum, such as: transmission/ transaction position, and objective/ process model; 2) the application of the above perspectives on the decisions of the nature and relationship of curriculum common places, such as: the selection of aims, goals and objectives, the selection of learning opportunities, the organization of learning opportunities, student evaluation; and 3) decisions on the change of the nature of curriculum common places after the introduction of compulsory schooling and recurrent education.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, MA Early Child Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Eng Lang Teach, MSc Math Edu, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, MA Prof Edu Psy, Doctor of Edu, PhD Edu & Master of Education Teach Key Sub Area (NETTI)
courses.course_syllabus:
\*Weeks 1-7 are designed in a way to help us better understand our common practices of curriculum design and implementation. Weeks 9 - 13 are designed in a way to explore how we can do it better with latest curriculum development theories and practices. That is, how can we teachers learn to become researchers so as to draw out the theoretical significance of our daily curriculum practices. Please also note that the topics and readings may change along the semester, if needed.

Week 1
Topic: Introduction to ‘curriculum’ and this course 課程的概念、意義及領域
Discussion Questions:What counts as ‘curriculum’, ‘curriculum consciousness’ + ‘critical thinking’? 課程領域有哪些範疇？課程意識和批判性思維如何培養？
Case: Pedagogical examples in HK and Mainland China classrooms

Week 2
Topic: Teaching-learning motivation and engagement 課程、教學與學習的關係
Discussion Questions: What are TARGET and ABC models? 課程、教學與學習之間有何關係？
Case: Classroom engagement analysis

Week 3
Topic: Backward Design Model + Tyler rationale I: Selecting learning goals 後向設計模型 + 泰勒原理四要素之一：學習目標
Discussion Questions: Why do we learn Tyler Rationale? How do we select learning goals? 為什麼需要學習泰勒原理？選取課程目標時需要考慮甚麼？
Case: Learning goals in HK & Mainland China/ University outcome-based approach

Week 4
Topic: Tyler Rationale II: Selecting learning experiences 泰勒原理四要素之二：學習體驗／經驗（課程內容）的選取
Discussion Questions: How do we select learning experiences? 有甚麼理論協助我們選取合宜的教學內容？
Case: 21st Core Competencies/ Skills

Week 5
Topic: Tyler Rationale III: Organizing learning experiences 泰勒原理四要素之三：課程組織（垂直水平、統整與分科）
Discussion Questions: How do we organize learning experiences? Horizontal & Vertical, Integrated & Subject 學習體驗／經驗如何組織？水平或垂直？統整與分科？
Case: Chinese, Math, and STEAM curricula

Week 6
Topic: Tyler Rationale IV: Evaluation and assessment 泰勒原理四要素之四：課程和教學評估 Possible guest speaker: TBD
Discussion Questions: How do we assess student learning? Formative vs. Summative Assessment 如何評估學生學習？形成性評估／總結性評估

Week 7
Topic: Guest lecture by Mrs. Dee Mulligan on Backward Design Model and Best Practice
Discussion Questions: Using Backward design model for unit design 思考後向設計與泰勒原理的關係

Week 8
Topic: Mid-term Project Presentation Conference
Discussion Questions: Share your unit design experiences with peers

Week 9
Topic: Alternative curriculum perspective and design 1: Joseph Schwab
Discussion Questions: Limits of Tyler Rationale + From Outcome to Context 泰勒原理的侷限性？從目標轉向場域
Case: Bohunt school incident

Week 10
Topic: Alternative curriculum perspective and design 2: William Pinar + Dwayne Huebner
Discussion Questions: Humanistic/ Cultural Regard in Curriculum 課程的人文文化性
Case: Curriculum subjects + language

Week 11
Topic: Alternative curriculum perspective and design 3: 佐藤學 & 歐用生
Discussion Questions: From Knowledge to Value; Mind to Body + Study從知識轉向價值；從理智轉向身體
Case: Embodied curriculum

Week 12
Topic: Latest curriculum development in HK and Mainland China + Curriculum theory and practice + Course review 課程理論和實踐
Discussion Questions: Cases: STEAM, e-learning, differentiated mode of instruction
Rethinking curriculum consciousness & teachers as researchers 再思課程意識的培養

Week 13
Topic: Guest Lecture by Dr. Marty Schmidt
Discussion Questions: Designing curricula for social conscience and inner awakening: Personal reflections

courses.description: Curriculum evaluation has an important role in the curriculum development process. This course aims at helping the participants broaden and deepen their understanding of the major theoretical, political and ethical issues in curriculum evaluation. It also focuses on the principles and skills of planning, designing and managing curriculum evaluation studies. Examples and case studies will be chosen in accordance with the background of the participants.

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Teaching: Orientation, Strategy and Application
courses.description: This course is designed to deepen and broaden participants' understanding of teaching, learning and knowledge. Characteristics that distinguish teaching approaches, divergent perceptions of learning, theories of knowledge acquisition, and theory of variation will be explored. Knowledge base of teachers, conceptualization of teachers' knowledge, teaching strategies, and constructive pedagogy will be discussed. Participants will be guided to reflect on their teaching practice and examine how teachers' knowledge can be studied, how teaching can be evaluated, and how class learning can be assessed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Eng Lang Teach, MSc Math Edu, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, MA Prof Edu Psy, Doctor of Edu, PhD Edu & Master of Education Teach Key Sub Area (NETTI)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. identify distinctive features characterizing teaching approaches, learning perceptions, and forms of knowledge
2. conceptualize teachers’ knowledge base and structure
3. comprehend the various ways of assessing teaching
4. reflect on their teaching practice

(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:
- Defining teaching; reasons underpinning one’s choice to teach
- Defining constructivism; cognitive constructivism vs. social constructivism; Zone of Proximal Development, scaffolding
- Curriculum orientation and the impacts on teachers’ teaching strategies
- Theories of action: espoused theory and theories-in-action; double-loop learning and single-loop learning; transmission, transaction, transformation; surface approach, and achieving approach to learning
- Identify the distinctive features characterizing teaching approaches ranging from teacher-directed to learner-centered
- Theories of knowledge: epistemology, rationalism, empiricism; Shulman’s seven knowledge domains; possible ways to study teachers’ knowledge
- Teaching quality, teaching competence, teaching effectiveness, and teacher efficacy; ways to assessing teaching quality

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Language Awareness for English Language Education
courses.description: This course is designed to raise the language awareness of participants who wish to improve the quality of their teaching and/ or conduct research in this area. The course focuses on the interrelationships between two aspects of English Language Education: subject content knowledge, i.e. what language teachers themselves need to know about language and communication, and pedagogic content knowledge, i.e. what to teach in order to enable language learners to become language users. The course provides participants with an introduction to: the nature of language and communication; the systems that govern languages use; and the aspects of current language research which are relevant to English Language Education and will enable participants to make informed judgments when identifying pedagogic content knowledge. The course seeks to enable participants to: (1) continue their own professional self-development as teachers and/ or researchers; and (2) become informed, critical consumers of research into English Language Education.

courses.description: This course begins with a review of the history and philosophy of science, which leads to an examination of the factors influencing the development and implementation of the science curriculum and an exploration of the various ways of curriculum evaluation. courses.title: Studies in Humanities Curriculum
courses.description: Built on the principles of curriculum design, this course examines (1) the deep-rooted cultural and social controversies that shape the aims of humanities curriculum, (2) the factors that influence content selection, (3) the challenges faced by schoolteachers in the course of implementation, and (4) the effects of different methods of evaluation. Beginning with the current situation of local curriculum development in Hong Kong, the course examines the place of humanities curriculum in recent curriculum reform through a historical as well as a theoretical perspective. Recent curriculum studies are reviewed to explore issues such as the effectiveness of subject teaching and integrated curriculum, the origin and significance of issue-enquiry approach. Analysis of case studies is adopted to tap from the experiences of different regions in the making of humanities curriculum, leading to a comparative study of the features of some major local humanities curricula.

They will have the knowledge and skills to enhance student well-being, motivation, engagement, and achievement, while also promoting their own professional growth and satisfaction as educators.

courses.title: Effective School Leadership
courses.description: This course aims to encourage students to reflect upon what constitutes effective leadership in schools, especially within a constantly shifting reform environment, and to construct their own ‘theories’ of effective leadership. A range of established and emerging approaches and understandings of leadership are explored and analyzed in relation to the assorted contexts within which leaders lead. While recognizing the importance of the principalship the course assumes that leadership resides and operates across various levels within and outside traditional school boundaries and that teacher leadership is an important area of study. Areas covered include strategic and ethical leadership, panel leadership, leadership for learning and comparative, cross-cultural understandings of leadership. The course attempts to locate school leadership at the local level within a broader national, regional and international perspective. Through a combination of case studies, journal writing, problem-based cases, experiential activities and self-guided learning students apply leadership knowledge to their own personal and school contexts.

Major concerns of this course include aims of education, structure and process of schooling, educational planning and finance, quality and equality of education, curriculum reform, teacher development and teacher education, and adult and non-formal education. The focus of discussion will mainly be on educational change in the Chinese Mainland, while relevant experiences in other Chinese societies will provide supplementary insights for reflection.

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Learning and the Brain
courses.description: Everyday, the brain is constantly shaped and tuned to support learning in this ever-changing world. However, learning can be tricky, as it may not always happen smoothly even when we try hard, but it can also happen without us being aware of the information. In this course, we will systematically examine how we learn, the basics about organization and functions of the brain, and how the brain is fundamentally changed by our experience. This course will help students to formulate better learning strategies, assess the scientific merits of claims relevant to learning and the brain, and appreciate how understanding the brain can inform education.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, Doctor of Edu & PhD Edu.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester, students should be able to
1. Describe the basic organization and functions of the brain.
2. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of issues related to learning and the brain.
3. Evaluate the merits, usefulness and limitations of scientific studies on tackling problems related to learning and the brain.
4. Apply theories and findings of research on learning and the brain to enhance learning efficiency.

(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:
Understanding the brain
- what is learning;
- how the brain works;

Learning to understand the world
- tuning to the visual and auditory world
- integrating the senses

Learning to solve problems
- remembering more and better
- learning without knowing

Better learning in the real world
- experts vs. novices
- learning difficulty, plasticity and aging
- education and the brain

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Educating Students with Special Needs
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with theoretical foundations of selected areas of special needs and help them to understand possible learning difficulties children with these special needs would encounter. These areas of special needs include: 1) learning disabilities; 2) giftedness and talents; 3) autism spectrum disorder; 4) attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; and 5) emotional and behavioral disorders. For each kind of special need, students will learn its characteristics, causes, and provision of special education in Hong Kong. Besides, this course will also prepare students for developing essential intervention strategies and techniques to help children with learning difficulties. Students will also work in small groups, under the supervision of the instructor, to conduct case studies in order to strengthen their knowledge of the learning difficulties of selected groups of children and adolescents.

4. develop relevant intervention strategies to facilitate student development and enhance learning in primary school years

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Parenthood in Life
courses.description: As suggested by the Existentialist school of thought, the "know-why" of parenthood will affect the "know-how" of parenting. What most parents really need is not simply the skills of parenting, but a commitment to parenthood. This course will cover the existential and developmental dimensions of parenthood, scrupulously interpreting the latent crisis and life momentum behind daily parenting practices. Equal attention will be given to the meanings and concerns, needs and opportunities, challenges and obstacles, and developmental effects of parenthood on the parents themselves from early parenthood to grandparenthood. The significance of offspring and future generation for the healthy development of a person as a self-actualizing and generative individual, as emphasized in humanistic psychology will be thoroughly discussed and analyzed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Chi Lang Edu, MA Early Child Edu, Master of Edu, MPhil Edu, MA Sch Improve & Leader, MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu, Doctor of Edu & PhD Edu.
courses.learning_outcomes:

1. Realize the existential concern in parenting
2. Comprehend the developmental effect of parenthood
3. Appreciate the connection between generativity and self-actualization in parenthood

courses.description: The purpose of the course is to provide a comprehensive account of the nature and impact of family-school-community (FSC) collaboration in education. The course will examine the relationship between family, school, and community for children‘s education, parents empowerment and school improvement. courses.description: Although there is a myriad of opinions on how parents are supposed to raise their children, they are often not based on scientific investigations of parenting. This course will systematically examine the theories and research on parenting cognitions and practices from a psychological perspective. courses.title: Curriculum Organization
courses.description: Different approaches in organizing school curricula are based on different rationale and conceptualization concerning curriculum activities in schools. The nature and forms of knowledge constitute an important component in understanding and designing school curricula. Other relevant factors include school structure and culture, teachers’ subject identity and status of subject, etc. In this course, the different ways of curriculum organization are delineated and evaluated in the light of epistemological considerations. Analysing the different areas of human experience and knowledge should lead to a reconceptualization of the task of organizing curriculum from a higher standpoint. In this course, the design and implementation problems of different ways of curriculum organization, such as discipline-based curriculum, integrated curriculum and modular curriculum in different stages of education will be studied. This exercise of reflection should better prepare course participants for the practical task of curriculum design.

courses.title: School Reform in a Global Context
courses.description: This course aims to provide an understanding of the major contextual forces that have shaped local school reform. It seeks to investigate the dynamics of school reform as a global phenomenon and analyze its impact on educational policy and administration at the international, societal, and institutional levels. School reform policies are often viewed as endeavors to enhance national competitiveness in the world arena. New administrative measures can also be perceived as means to attain efficiency and effectiveness. These will be examined. By referring to the experiences of countries, mostly developed ones, which have influenced the direction of local school reform, and drawing insights from relevant research findings, this course will address critical issues in key areas of school reform in this part of the world. Topics to be discussed in this course will include: change in conception of human capital and reform in educational administration, school governance, resource allocation, curricula and teaching, quality assurance, teacher and principal preparations, leadership practices and so on.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Qualitative Research Methodology
courses.description: This course is designed to cultivate the research ability of doctoral students in adopting the qualitative research approach. To achieve this aim, we place emphasis on the discussion of highly selected exemplary qualitative studies that cover diversified types. To create the condition for thorough deliberation of the reading materials, which constitutes a prerequisite for fruitful discussions, the class meetings are held every two weeks. Where appropriate, the class discussion would be supplemented by the contribution of guest speakers and hands-on research training. By way of class discussion and out-of-class activities, we shall bring out for debates major theoretical, practical, and ethical issues involved in the following decisions throughout the research process: how to design a qualitative study so as to address research questions raised at the outset, what are relevant data that could answer the research questions, how to choose appropriate research methods to collect such relevant data, how to analyse and interpret qualitative data (of various types), and how to present the collected data. Fundamental issues in conducting a qualitative study, ranging from the role of a theoretical or conceptual framework, through the access to subjective, intersubjective, and objective knowledge, to the establishment of its validity and reliability, will also be deliberated.

courses.course_syllabus:
Despite the limitations of survey research, it provides well-accepted norms and references for the continuous improvement of education. This course equips doctoral students with advanced statistical techniques (e.g., multiple regression, ANCOVA, MANOVA, repeated measures MANOVA, principal components and factor analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, structural equation modeling, multilevel/ hierarchical linear models, brief coverage: logistic regression, discriminant analysis, canonical analysis). As large-scale national or international surveys (e.g., PISA, TIMSS, and NAEP) have become increasingly important, these high quality data will be used for hands-on practice together with any other high quality quantitative data that students might have collected themselves.

Potential research topics include: (1) comparing Hong Kong (or other Asian economies) against western economies in the recent cycle, (2) examining the trends of Hong Kong in the last two decades, (3) examining the universality of psychological or educational theories across many economies, and (4) examining the relations among various aspects of teaching, family background, parental practices, and students’ well-being. Students are responsible for linking the data analyses with appropriate theoretical frameworks.

The course will provide a basic introduction to advanced analytical procedures. Then students will have to (1) identify suitable constructs in the appropriate surveys, (2) formulate hypotheses, (3) conduct analyses and explore relations, and (4) draw up conclusions and write up results for publication. Students have to make frequent presentations and actively discuss classmates’ proposals and results.

Students are expected to have acquired fundamental research knowledge before enrolling PEDU7303.

courses.description: This course is designed for doctoral students who want to conduct a qualitative research project. The course will offer the multifaceted and advanced knowledge needed for such work, plus core techniques commonly used in the qualitative research paradigm. Providing students with a comprehensive and sophisticated understanding of philosophical stances underpinning different qualitative methodologies will help them situate their research and shape the deployment of their qualitative inquiry in an informed manner. The course will concentrate on developing students' knowledge and practical skills for conducting qualitative research in the following areas: (1) the use of relevant explanatory and exploratory research questions in different qualitative studies; (2) writing a critical literature review and theoretical sensitivity; (3) formulating a research protocol and the practice of triangulation; (4) hands-on experiences of collecting qualitative data with relevant data collection techniques; (5) data interpretation and analysis through coding practices based on the content analysis approach; (6) having theory building with the application of grounded theory; (7) developing skills to draw conclusions and write reports, both of which serve as the basis for preparing a doctoral research proposal and/or thesis; (8) special attention will be given to the issue of ‘researcher as instrument’ and related ethical issues. To put the knowledge acquired into practice, students will be required to undertake a mini qualitative project individually with rigorous research design. It is anticipated that students will gain the competency to interpret and report their research findings in an academic manner.

courses.title: Selected Topics in the Science of Learning
courses.description: Is scientific approach in educational research possible? What constitute scientific evidence in educational research? In recent years, even though the call for more evidence-based educational practices has become ubiquitous, new instructional innovations and practices have been implemented faster than the accumulation of research evidence. In this course, we will first discuss the meaning of scientific approach in educational research that have shaped the current landscape of the field. Then, we will discuss how this approach enhances the understanding of recent instructional innovations and practices for the improvement of students’ learning. Students of this course are expected to learn about both “form” (i.e., methodology) and “substance” (i.e., content) of educational research by critical analysis of the literature in order to become prepared for leading roles in instructional innovations and practices.

courses.subject: PEDU
courses.title: Selected Topics in Psychosocial Development
courses.description: Humans do not grow and develop in a vacuum. From birth, our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are shaped by the dynamic interplay of our genetic makeup and the environment. As children develop, they constantly make sense of the social world around them. Their social cognition, in turn, guides their interactions with others. Indeed, a major goal of socialization is for children to develop the ability to understand and act effectively on the social environment, so that they can function as accepted and competent members of their societies. In this course, we will examine children’s psychosocial development. Potential topics include the nature of human development, achievement motivation, family process and parenting, and changes in youth emotional functioning and interpersonal relationships.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Education; Doctor of Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to:
1. Describe the complex and dynamic nature of children’s psychosocial development.
2. Critically analyze the roles of different contextual factors in children’s psychosocial development.
3. Conduct simple, systematic investigations of children’s psychosocial development.

courses.title: M.Phil. Seminar in Educational Studies I
courses.description: Students have to fulfill all the course requirements and satisfy the required attendance. This course is designed to familiarize students with the principles, structure and process of education research, and it is organized into two parts. The first part is in the form of lecture which takes up the first seven sessions of the courses. It aims to provide students with a general understanding of the nature and substance of education research. Thus, topics to be covered in these lectures are major paradigms in education inquiry, the philosophical and ethical issues relating to education research, and the basic principles and procedures in education research. The second part of the course is organized in the form of seminar during the two semesters. Each seminar is conducted by a research student in the Division of Education and is supervised by no less than two members of the teaching staff of the Faculty of Education. Depending on the research interests of the research students conducting the seminars, research ideas and plans in educational studies will be critically reviewed and discussed. (For M.Phil. students only.)
